body.head: Two New York Brooklyn boys.
body.p: Here in the same apartment (Ward 6, Campbell Hospital,) are two young soldiers from Brooklyn, members of that noble and oldone of the bravest of the brave.war‑worn regiment the 51st New York Volunteers. I knew both these two soldiers when they were childrenfor they were lived in the same town,—so they are near to me One of them, J. L. has lost an arm, and lies there with the stump slowly healing. He is but a boy of 19 or 20, with a good look, and about as young as he is. true about as good a soldier as they make them. I saw him at Fredericksburgh, lying on the ground, all bloody—his arm had just been amputated. He was cooly munching away at a cracker, and made no fuss. about the set of James he was sent up from the front and furnished with quarters here. He will recover, but is full of fight yet—wants to meet the secessionists and have a pop at them yet. A. H. V., another of my br the other of these the two, is an equally good young soldier, and full of unflagging good nature—he is the life of the end of the Ward where he lies. He has badly frozen feet.
